INTRODUCTORY.

In presenting *this, the first of the Regular Series of Directories,

the publisher need only say to the citizens, that experience, combined

with strenuous efforts and a liberal outlay, has brought forth a

Directory which needs very little prefacing, nor demands much

indulgence. To the stranger, he would say that it is a representative

book of the city.

Special attention is invited to the Appendix Department, pages 17

to 53, it will be found to contain a vast amount of general and

useful information not usually contained in a Directory, all obtained

from the proper sources. The Post Office Directory, in the back of

the book, is another valuable feature in this work.

The Advertising Department, while not so extensive as to make

the work profitable, 'represents the leading and best houses in their

respective lines, and the publisher hereby extends hearty thanks to

those who have appreciated and encouraged the work.

The lack of any Board or organization keeping statistics, precludes

the possibility of giving the figures and data of Columbus business.

The numbering of the city is. very incomplete, and is a source of

great .inconvenience to citizen as well as stranger. This, however,

can be easily and cheaply remedied by the proper authorities.

A great deal may be said of the manufacturing advantages of

Columbus, but we show, herein, by pointing to facts, that it is the

leading city of the South, proper, in manufacturing, already, and

naught but facts, comes within the province of a directory publisher.

The water power and location are simply unsurpassed.

A careful census was taken in connection with the Directory,

the figures include the residents and those having business in

Columbus: Whites, 9,435; colored, 6,588; total, 16,023.

Columbus was incorporated in 1829. In 1848 she had 5,074 souls,

white and colored, and in 1860 a total of 9,039, in the city proper; the

present volume contains 4,700 names--3,658 white, and 1,042 colored,

against 2,713 contained in the Directory of 1873, and if we follow the

custom of most cities in ascertaining the population, by multiplying

the number of names by 4, it would show a population of 18,800. But

this mode is no criterion in a manufacturing city like Columbus.

In conclusion the publisher would state that lie proposes to con

tinue the publication of the Columbus City Directory at regular

intervals in the future, and, as he believes this volume will be

acknowledged vastly superior to those heretofore published, so it

will be his honest endeavor to make each succeeding work ah im

provement on those which have preceded it.

Very Respectfully,

August, 1878.

A. E. SIIOLES, Publisher.

Crawford street is the dividing line, running east and west, the river is the initial point, North and South. North and South streets are numbered from Crawford, (except Broad street, that is numbered from Franklin, south.) East and West Streets are numbered from the river, east. REGISTERED LETTER DE PARTMENT.--R. I). Locke, reg ister clerk. Office opens at 8 a. m. and closes at 5i p. m. Valua ble letters or packages should be registered, the fee for same, to all parts of the world, being ten cents, in addition to the regular rates of letter postage, to be paid in stamps, i. e., stamps sufficient must be attached to letters before presenting for registration. - The

name and post office address of the sender must be endorsed on face of envelope. After a regis tered letter has been transmitted, it cannot be recalled by the sender.

No letter can be registered on Sunday. The Post Office Depart-, ment, or its revenue, is not by law" liable for the loss of any registered mail matter, but will vigorously prosecute the search for any reg istered package reported lost. Reg istered letters will not be delivered to any person but the one to whom they are addressed, or to a person the postmaster knows to be au thorized to receive them.

in full, or it cannot be forwarded. Any writing, either inside or out side of the wrapper, except the address and name of parties send ing, subjects the above articles to letter postage.
